title: Chest Pain
summary: Evaluating and responding to chest pain, which can indicate heart attack or other serious conditions requiring immediate medical attention.

steps.title: Take Chest Pain Seriously
steps.description: All chest pain should be evaluated urgently. Heart attack pain: pressure, squeezing, fullness in center of chest lasting >15 minutes. May radiate to arms, back, neck, jaw. Call 911 immediately.

steps.title: Call 911 and Give Aspirin
steps.description: Call 911 for emergency transport. While waiting, give adult aspirin (325mg) if not allergic - have them chew it. This helps prevent blood clots. Do not drive person to hospital yourself.

steps.title: Position Comfortably
steps.description: Help person to comfortable position - usually sitting up or semi-reclined. Loosen tight clothing. Keep calm and reassure them. If prescribed nitroglycerin, help them take it.

steps.title: Monitor Symptoms
steps.description: Note: time pain started, what they were doing, pain description (sharp, dull, crushing), other symptoms (nausea, sweating, shortness of breath). This helps emergency responders.

steps.title: Prepare for Emergency Care
steps.description: Gather medications list and insurance information if available. Stay with person. If they become unconscious and stop breathing, begin CPR. Have someone wait outside to direct ambulance.

warnings: Never ignore chest pain - it's better to be safe
Women, elderly, and diabetics may have atypical symptoms
Do not delay calling 911 to 'see if it gets better'
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 immediately for any unexplained chest pain
Call 911 urgently for chest pain with shortness of breath, sweating, or nausea
Any chest pain lasting more than a few minutes needs evaluation
preventionTips: Know your heart disease risk factors
Don't ignore warning signs like chest discomfort with exertion
Keep aspirin accessible at home and work
